body.header:
Look carefully at the bar chart and the table and complete the report by choosing the word, phrase or number which best fits each gap.
Writing Task 1

section.p: The bar chart depicts world population growth since""by""until""in"" 1804 and shows the predicted world population by""until""from""since"" 2050. The table compares the distribution of the global population between more and less developed parts of the world in 2001 and 2050. The chart shows that the world's population has grown""is growing""grows""grew"" at a rapid pace over the last two centuries. In""Until""Since""From"" 1804 there were 1 billion people in the world. By 1927, 123 years later, the population had doubled""has doubled""doubled""was doubling"". Remarkably, it only took another 47""33""60""74"" years for the population to double once again. By the turn of the millennium, the population had risen by""up""for""to"" another 2.1 billion. If this upward trend continues, it is predicted that by 2050 the number of people sharing the planet will have risen""rises""will be rising""is rising"" to just over 9 billion. As regards how the global population is distributed, the table shows that less developed regions account for by far the greatest proportion of people in the world. It also reveals that regional population trends are expected to vary considerably. Large population increases""fluctuations""decreases""percentages"" are projected for less developed regions, particularly for the least developed countries""towns""cities""regions"" within them. By 2050 the population of the former will have increased by just under two-thirds""a quarter""a half""three-quarters"", while that of the latter will have almost trebled""halved""doubled""quadrupled"". In sharp contrast, the population of more developed regions is expected to drop""plunge""rise""peak"" slightly. As a result, the 8""2""5""10"" billion people living in less developed regions in 2050 will account for almost 9 out of every 10 people on earth. To sum up, the rapid population growth the planet has experienced""experiences""experienced""had experienced"" since the early 19th century is set to continue well into the first half of the present century. However, it is the growing""sharp""dramatic""upward"" population of the developing world that will account for this increase.

p.font: since: The figures come up to the present, so present perfect is appropriate here.
by/until: The chart doesn't include figures for years before 1804.
in: The chart is not only about the year 1804.
by: It is the correct answer.
until: The graph doesn't show predicted populations for years between 2001 and 2050. If it did, then it would be possible to use 'until' here.
from: This would mean, 'beginning in 2050', which isn't what the chart shows.
since: 'Since' is used when referring to a period that begins at some point in the past and continues to the present. It isn't used to refer to a point in the future.
has grown: It is the correct answer.
is growing: The graph doesn't only refer to the present situation.
grows: Notice that this sentence and the chart refer to the 'last two centuries'.
grew: The chart and this sentence refer to a period which comes up to the present, not to just one point in the past.
In: It is the correct answer.
Until: The chart doesn't include figures for years before 1804.
Since: The tense of the main verb in this sentence is past simple. 'Since' is not suitable here.
From: 'From' is used to refer to the beginning of a period, but this sentence refers to one particular point in time – 1804.
had doubled: The time phrase at the beginning of the sentence, 'By 1927', makes past perfect necessary here.
has doubled: This sentence refers only to the past.
doubled: Notice the time phrase at the beginning of the sentence, 'By 1927'.
was doubling: There is no need for a continuous tense here.
33/60: Check the years on the horizontal axis. What was the population in 1927? By when had it doubled?

74: You are not looking for a date, but for how many years it took for the population to double. Check the years on the horizontal axis. What was the population in 1927? How many years did it take to double?
by: It is the correct answer.
up: The verb 'rise' isn't followed with 'up'. Have you confused this with the phrase 'go up'?
to: 2.1 billion is not the figure reached, but the amount the population increased over that period.
will have risen: It is the correct answer.
rises/will be rising/is rising: Notice that time phrase 'by 2050'. Which tense is used with 'by'?
increases: It is the correct answer.
fluctuations: 'Fluctuation' means 'ups and downs', in other words no steady trend in either direction.

decreases: Check the table again. 'Developing regions' means those countries which are still developing. In the table, these are referred to as 'Less developed regions.' What changes are predicted for these regions?
percentages: Neither the table nor the chart refers to percentages.
countries: It is the correct answer.
towns/cities/regions: Read the column and row headings for the table again carefully.
two-thirds: 'The former' refers to 'Less developed regions'. The population for these is projected to rise from 4.94 billion to 8.14 billion.
a quarter/a half/three-quarters: 'The former' refers to 'Less developed regions'. Check the predicted rise for these regions in the table again.
trebled: 'The latter' refers to the 'Less developed countries'. The predicted population rise for these countries is from 0.68 billion to 1.83 billion.
halved/doubled/quadrupled: 'The latter' refers to the 'Less developed countries'. Check the predicted population rise for these countries in the table.
drop: From 1.19 billion to 1.18 billion.
plunge: A 'plunge' can't be slight.
rise: Check the table again more carefully.
peak: If a figure 'peaks' it reaches its high point. The table only has two figures to compare, so we can't really talk about a 'peak'.
8: This is the correct answer.
2/5/10: Check the table again.
has experienced: Present perfect is the appropriate tense here because of the use of 'since'. The time period referred to comes up to the present.
experiences/experienced: Notice the use of 'since' in this sentence. Which tense is best to use here?
had experienced: The sentence refers to a period which begins in the past and continues up to the present.
growing: This is the correct answer.
sharp: We use 'sharp' with words such as 'rise', 'increase' or 'fall'.
dramatic: We use 'dramatic' with words such as 'rise' or 'fall'.
upward: We use 'upward' with the word 'trend'.
